description: From Middle English tens, from Old French tens (modern French temps), from Latin tempus. Doublet of tempo and tempus.

entries.meaning: (grammar, countable) Any of the forms of a verb which distinguish when an action or state of being occurs or exists.
examples: The basic tenses in English are present, past, and future.

entries.meaning: (linguistics, grammar, countable) An inflected form of a verb that indicates tense.
examples: English only has a present tense and a past tense; it has no future tense.

entries.meaning: (linguistics, uncountable) The property of indicating the point in time at which an action or state of being occurs or exists.
examples: Dyirbal verbs are not inflected for tense.

verbs.description: tense (third-person singular simple present tenses, present participle tensing, simple past and past participle tensed)

entries.meaning: (grammar, transitive) To apply a tense to.

description: Borrowed from Latin tēnsus, one form of the past participle of tendō (“stretch”). Ultimately identical to Etymology 1.

entries.meaning: Showing signs of stress or strain; not relaxed.
examples: You need to relax, all this overtime and stress is making you tense.

verbs.description: tense (third-person singular simple present tenses, present participle tensing, simple past and past participle tensed)
